JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
VOL. XVIII, NO. 7.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 24, 1913.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

NOTED SCIENTISTS SPEAK HERE

THE FACULTY "LETS SOPHS OFF"

TWO MEN QUALIFY FOR RHODES' FOOTBALL GAME IS CALLED OFF

Twenty-one Members of the National
Academy Read Papers During Twoday Session in Physics Laboratory.

It Relieves 28 Second-Year Men of the
"Disabilities"—Student Council
Receives News First.

Julian Marshall and Carl Weber, Both
News-Letter Men, Eligible for
the Rhodes Scholarship.

Death of Wray of Gettysburg, Causes the
Contest to Be Cancelled -Players
Watched St. Johns at Work.

Twenty-one of the most distinguished scientists of this country
were speakers at the two-day session of the National Academy of
Sciences last Tuesday and Wednesday in the physics laboratory. The
meeting was one of the most important events on the scientific calendar of the academic year.
Papers limited to "short time"
were read, and, while some were of
a very technical style, they were all
enjoyed by members of the faculty,
students and the general public that
attended.
The academy is composed of one
hundred and thirty-five specialists in
scientific work of America and Canada. Dr. William H. Welch, head
of Hopkins, is president. He was
recently elected for a term of five
years. The University has ten members: Dr. Abel, pharmacology; Dr.
Ames, physics; Dr. Clark, geology;
Dr. Howell, physiology; Dr. Mace,
anatomy; Dr. Morse, chemistry;
Dr. Reid, geology; Dr. Remsen,
chemistry; Dr. Welch, pathology;
• and Dr. Wood, physics.
Among the more noted speakers
were Dr. S. Weir Mitchell, who
gave a biographical memoir of Dr.
John S. Billings, the Civil War
physician, who later became interested in the establishment of the
Johns Hopkins Medical School:
Dr. Simon Flexner, formerly of
Hopkins, now of the Rockefeller
Institute; Dr. C. B. Davenport,
head of the government eugenical
work at Cold Spring Harbor; Dr.
Howard A. Kelly, of Hopkins, who
told of his clinic for radium cures;
Dr. Harry Fielding Reid, who spoke
on earthquakes and tidal waves;
and Dr. Harry C. Jones, who talked
of light absorption.
The complete list of speakers
follows:

At a meeting last Friday afternoon the faculty committee announced through the Student Council that all the penalties imposed
on the sophomores for the recent
hazing episode were to be removed
on Tuesday, November 25. This
action comes in time to enable the
sophomores to see the St. John's
game, to hold the interclass football game and to attend the first
cotillon.
The four now famous conditions,
which are to be void on Tuesday,
are:
First—They shall take no part in
the exercises of athletic teams and
musical clubs.
Second—They shall be excluded
from the gymnasium building.
Third—They shall not be present
at any game, concert or dance given
under the auspices of the students.
Fourth—That the probation shall
continue until February 1.
Their issuance caused intense excitement among the undergraduates
and a mass-meeting was called,
which jammed Hopkins Hall. Redhot speeches were the order of the
day; many went so far as to urge
a general strike. Shortly after 2
o'clock the cooler heads prevailed
and the sophomores were assured
that if they "signed" their fellowstudents would unanimously endeavor to have "the mild disabilities" (mirabile dictu!) removed.
Organized effort was made to
present to the faculty, individually
and collectively, the student viewpoint. It was soon apparent that
the sympathy, which would naturally have been with the authorities if a strike had been declared,
was now totally with the students.
Moreover, it was realized that no
further advantage could be gained
by the full continuance of the faculty cOnditions.

It was announced last week by
the authorities at Oxford that
Julian H. Marshall, A.B. '13, and
Carl J. Weber, '14, have passed
the qualifying examinations in
Latin and mathematics for the
Rhodes Scholarship to be awarded
this year for the session beginning
October, 1914.
Mr. Marshall, who received his
bachelor's degree with the Class
of 1913, is well known to all Hopkins students as a member of the
famous championship lacrosse team
of 1913. In addition to this, he
was a member of the editorial
board of THE NEWS-LETTER, assistant manager of the lacrosse
team (1910-11, 1911-12), member
of the Glee Club, and assistant business manager of the Km "Hullabaloo." He is a good all-round
man.
Mr. Weber, who will be graduated as a bachelor of arts next
June, is the president of the Grotins Society. He is also an assistant editor of THE NEws-LETTER, sings first bass in the Glee
Club, and is a member of the Instrumental Club.
Charles Leland Getz. '13, is still
in the competition. Getz was a
mighty worker while in collerre,
and has a tremendous list after his
name in the 1913 year book. He
ran a sharp race for the scholarship last year with Emory Niles.
But it is believed that family objections may keep "Getzie" from
offering his name.
The winner of the scholarship is
sure to be a Hopkins man. The
Selection by the three presidents
will be made before Christmas.

Owing to the death of Homer
Wray, one of the members of their
squad, the Gettysburg football team
was unable to play the game with
Hopkins scheduled for last Saturday. The announcement of this
fact caused much disappointment
among the Hopkins rooters, for all
had expected to see a well-played
contest.
The Hopkins football team went
in a body to Oriole Park to see
St. John's play Washington College, in hopes of getting an idea
of what kind of game St. John's
may be expected to put up next
Thursday.

Details of Wray's Death.

Gettysburg, Pa., November 22.—
Homer H. Wray, of Leechburg,
Pa., a student at Gettysburg College, died late last night from the
effects of an injury sustained in a
football game between the Gettysburg and Dickinson College reserve
teams at Carlisle three weeks ago.
Wray had one of the bones in his
chest fractured. Abscesses formed
on the lungs and caused his death.
St. John's Next.

The 'Varsity has now but one
more game, and that the most important of the season, to play. St.
John's will be no easy opponent,
and realizing this the Black and
Blue will put in the three hardest
days of practice of the year, beginning today. There will be scrimmage today and tomorrow, and
light signal drills Wednesday.
Hopkins is favored to win the
battle against St. John's, but the
odds are slight in betting. The
teams are about equal in weight.
A great turnout of Hopkins and
St. John's rooters is expected.
Both student bodies will have bands.
St. John's its student organization
and Hopkins hired talent. The
rooters will assemble at headquarters and parade to the field.
Hopkins cheering and demonstrations will be in charge of "Butts"
Sutton. St. John's has a number
of leaders.
Should Hopkins win it will have,
lost four and won three games during the season. As the defeats
were mostly at the hands of such
teams as Swarthmore and Carlisle,
whom Hopkins could not hope to
beat, the Hopkins followers do not
feel ashamed of the record of their
team. Stevens and Western Maryland have been the only teams to
fall before the Black and Blue this
season.

THE NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 24, 1913.

JOEL GUTMAN & CO.

MEETING OF GROTIUS SOCIETY

WHAT CLASS OF 1912 IS DOING

112 to 122 N. Eutaw St.

Fall Election of Officers Was Held Last
Tuesday—Mr. Hammond Renders
Some Choice Selections.

Various Vocations of Some of the Members Who Are in Pursuit of the
Coin of the Realm.

The Grotius Society held its
regular meeting at one o'clock last
Tuesday in the Donovan Room. A
quorum of seniors was present.
The fall election of officers was
held, the following being elected:
I. W. Nachlas, '][4., president;
H. W. Richmond, '14, vice-president; A. Schaffer,
secretary;
A. R. Gminder, '14, treasurer, and
C. S. Levy, '15, curator.
The discussion announced for the
meeting was woman suffrage, but
this led on to the question of women in general. Mr. A. L. Hammond read some choice selections
from Schopenhauer's remarks on
women. Not all those present
agreed with the philosopher, especially when he says such things
as: "It is only the man whose intellect is clouded by his sexual impulses that could give the name of
the fair sex to that undersized, narrow-shouldered, broad-hipped and
short-legged race !" The discussion
was very interesting to all who attended. The officers of the Society
regret that not more of the new
men are showing interest. All students will be welcome at the next
meeting—Tuesday, at one, Donovan
Room.

H. G. Du Bois, A.B.'12, is teaching at the Jefferson School.
G. P. Thomas III is with his
father in the rubber business.
Harry Dickey, A.B. '12, is working in his father's cotton mills in
the city.
Dudley Carrol, A.B. '12, is with
the street railroad company at
Portland, Ore.
"Jimmy" Easter, A.B. '12. after
surviving one year at Boston Tech:
is trying to repeat.
James Johnston Corner, Jr., A.B.
'12, and T. Brooke Price, A.B. '12,
are at the Harvard Law School.
"Bill" Gail, A.B. '12, who started
to go to Tech. with "Jimmy," but
soon quit, is now studying engineering at Cornell.
H. S. Applebaum, A.B. '12; W.
E. Grempler, A.B. '12, and A. C.
Sutton, A.B. '12, are at the Johns
Hopkins Medical School.
M. E. Hopkins, A.B. '12 ; "Johnny" Huck, A.B.'is; "Freddie" Lee,
A.B. '12; Huntley Lloyd, A.B. '12,
and Max Paulus, A.B. '12, are all
taking ,graduate work in chemistry
at the University.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOV. 24, 1913.
We're Ready, St. John's!

"Come on, St. John's, we're
ready !" We are drawing to a close
a football season that has been
fraught with surprises and disappointments, but we still have that
same sand in our makeup and hair
on our chests that took the vigor
and enjoyment out of your serpentine gyrations on the field year before last. Your snake dance then
was spiritless. It was just a matterof-fact affair that was but a worm's
wiggle to our piedbal claimant.
Your dance will be the same Thursday, that is, if there is any at all.
We are going to win the battle,
St. John's! Harsh words, but true.
Our boys are there. And we shall
'• be there, too. You will see us sitting in the west end of the east
grandstand with our hired band.
Smiles will be on our faces and a
big total on our side of the scoreboard. And we are going to sing
those beautiful songs. We are going to call you "Naughty Boy."
Our hired cymbals and b-flat cornets are going to penetrate the air
with paens of great joy and thanksgiving. It will be pretty to observe,
as "Pepys" would say.
So, come up, St. John's! Come
up with your shoes shined and your
dress uniforms all pressed up nice
and sleek, as the St. John's Collegian always urges you to do when
you take a visit with your team.
We want to see you all again. We
like to hear your pretty band and
see the"cold, red cheeks of your
student bass hornist suddenly give
up their big jowl of merry wind
as your passes are incompleted.
Come on, St. John's, we're
ready! In the glistening sphere of
fate we see eleven men downcast in
black with miriads of yellow stripes
around their arms slowly retreating
from a sod-torn field. We see a
black and blue• clad team wildly
throwing its nose and head-guards
in the air with great joy. A crowd

of . cheering students holding high
great flags and blue banners take
the field. They form a giant "H,"
and then they dance.

The Honor System.

THE NEWS-LETTER prints in a
prominent place on the first page of
this issue the set of resolutions
framed by the Student Council that
are intended to put all undergraduates on their honor during examinations, provided the student body
adopts the resolutions at a massmeeting to be held at i o'clock
Wednesday in Hopkins Hall.
It may appear from the prominence given the matter, however,
that dishonesty during examinations
has come to be flagrant at the Hopkins, but we are glad to be able to
say that it has not.
Every school, college and university in this and other countries has
had, at some time or other, among
its students some who have violated
the confidence placed in them by
professors and instructors, and
Hopkins has had a few such men.
The Student Council has been
prompted to try to make this few
none. Its resolutions convey the
spirit and idea of abolishment.
They are to be presented to the students, and debate and amendments
will be in order. But, however
few or many be the changes in the
resolutions, it is intended that they
will finally be adopted, with the idea
that undergraduates in the examination rooms will be under a moral
pledge not to receive or furnish
any assistance.
The Council's initiative in this
matter is highly commendable. It
has, on several other occasions, won
victories in the regulation of student affairs, and all of them have
been steps forward in self-government. Its latest plan, that to put
in practice the honor system, is
especially fine in spirit, and it is
to be hoped that Wednesday's
mass-meeting will be a notable
gathering of students demanding
the abolishment of all semblances
of dishonesty and the establishment
of a high code of student morals.
We Sympathize With Gettysburg.

The entire student body of the
Johns Hopkins University is distressed at the news of the death of
Homer H. Wray, of the Gettysburg football squad.
Hopkins knows how the Soldiers
feel now that one of their men has
fallen on the field, a martyr to football. Closed gates and a quiet field
at Homewood were our share of the
sadness, but that can not compare
with the gloom that rests on the
Pennsylvania college today.
We sympathize with Gettysburg.

Class Tournament Planned.

The Johns Hopkins Chess Club
held its reorganization meeting in
the chapel last Thursday. Officers
elected for the ensuing year are as
follows: President,Yokoyama ; vicepresident,Chenoweth,'14; secretary,
Schaffer, '14. The officers constitute the executive committee.
It was definitely decided to drop
last year's uncompleted tournament
and to start a new round-robin as
soon as possible. Those who desire
to enter the tournament should
hand their 'lames to one of the
board. The entry fee, a nominal
one, is twenty-five cents. Three
handsome prizes will be awarded to
the winners of the tournament.
The Society will challenge the
chess club of the University of
Georgetown to a match to be held
in the Hopkins Club about the middle of January. A team of six men
will be picked from those who come
out highest in the tournament, and
as all but two of last year's team,
which beat Georgetown, is back, we
have good hopes of repeating our
victory Of last year.

MID - CITY TERMINALS

successful at many other institutions where it has been adopted.
A very good example of this fact
is what happened at one of the
largest boarding schools in the
United States, where I went before
I came here. In the senior dormitory, as in all dormitories, smoking
was prohibited. The enforcement
of this rule wa's carried out, as well
as possible, by the masters in the
"dorm." However, the architecture
of the building offered many Opportunities for smoking without being
caught. The masters (lid their best
to stop it, but where there are so
many boys together it is hard to
know what each other is doing, and
the smoking in the "dorm" grew
worse and worse. Finally, after a
meeting of the house was called, we
agreed that every fellow would be
put on his honor not to smoke in
the "dorm." It worked to perfection and re-established friendships
between masters and boys,which had
been broken up on account of the
formers' everlasting spying. Only
one fellow, I may add, was ever
caught doing it after this agreement
and he was tended to sufficiently
by the rest of us.
This is my own experience of
\\ hat an excellent thing the "honor
system.' is and I sincerely hope
that it will be adopted here.

JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY

NOTED SCIENTISTS SPEAK HERE

THE FACULTY "LETS SOPHS OFF"

TWO MEN QUALIFY FOR RHODES' FOOTBALL GAME IS CALLED OFF

Twenty-one Members of the National
Academy Read Papers During Twoday Session in Physics Laboratory.

It Relieves 28 Second-Year Men of the
"Disabilities"—Student Council
Receives News First.

Julian Marshall and Carl Weber, Both
News-Letter Men, Eligible for
the Rhodes Scholarship.

Death of Wray of Gettysburg, Causes the
Contest to Be Cancelled -Players
Watched St. Johns at Work.

Twenty-one of the most distinguished scientists of this country
were speakers at the two-day session of the National Academy of
Sciences last Tuesday and Wednesday in the physics laboratory. The
meeting was one of the most important events on the scientific calendar of the academic year.
Papers limited to "short time"
were read, and, while some were of
a very technical style, they were all
enjoyed by members of the faculty,
students and the general public that
attended.
The academy is composed of one
hundred and thirty-five specialists in
scientific work of America and Canada. Dr. William H. Welch, head
of Hopkins, is president. He was
recently elected for a term of five
years. The University has ten members: Dr. Abel, pharmacology; Dr.
Ames, physics; Dr. Clark, geology;
Dr. Howell, physiology; Dr. Mace,
anatomy; Dr. Morse, chemistry;
Dr. Reid, geology; Dr. Remsen,
chemistry; Dr. Welch, pathology;
• and Dr. Wood, physics.
Among the more noted speakers
were Dr. S. Weir Mitchell, who
gave a biographical memoir of Dr.
John S. Billings, the Civil War
physician, who later became interested in the establishment of the
Johns Hopkins Medical School:
Dr. Simon Flexner, formerly of
Hopkins, now of the Rockefeller
Institute; Dr. C. B. Davenport,
head of the government eugenical
work at Cold Spring Harbor; Dr.
Howard A. Kelly, of Hopkins, who
told of his clinic for radium cures;
Dr. Harry Fielding Reid, who spoke
on earthquakes and tidal waves;
and Dr. Harry C. Jones, who talked
of light absorption.
The complete list of speakers
follows:

At a meeting last Friday afternoon the faculty committee announced through the Student Council that all the penalties imposed
on the sophomores for the recent
hazing episode were to be removed
on Tuesday, November 25. This
action comes in time to enable the
sophomores to see the St. John's
game, to hold the interclass football game and to attend the first
cotillon.
The four now famous conditions,
which are to be void on Tuesday,
are:
First—They shall take no part in
the exercises of athletic teams and
musical clubs.
Second—They shall be excluded
from the gymnasium building.
Third—They shall not be present
at any game, concert or dance given
under the auspices of the students.
Fourth—That the probation shall
continue until February 1.
Their issuance caused intense excitement among the undergraduates
and a mass-meeting was called,
which jammed Hopkins Hall. Redhot speeches were the order of the
day; many went so far as to urge
a general strike. Shortly after 2
o'clock the cooler heads prevailed
and the sophomores were assured
that if they "signed" their fellowstudents would unanimously endeavor to have "the mild disabilities" (mirabile dictu!) removed.
Organized effort was made to
present to the faculty, individually
and collectively, the student viewpoint. It was soon apparent that
the sympathy, which would naturally have been with the authorities if a strike had been declared,
was now totally with the students.
Moreover, it was realized that no
further advantage could be gained
by the full continuance of the faculty cOnditions.

It was announced last week by
the authorities at Oxford that
Julian H. Marshall, A.B. '13, and
Carl J. Weber, '14, have passed
the qualifying examinations in
Latin and mathematics for the
Rhodes Scholarship to be awarded
this year for the session beginning
October, 1914.
Mr. Marshall, who received his
bachelor's degree with the Class
of 1913, is well known to all Hopkins students as a member of the
famous championship lacrosse team
of 1913. In addition to this, he
was a member of the editorial
board of THE NEWS-LETTER, assistant manager of the lacrosse
team (1910-11, 1911-12), member
of the Glee Club, and assistant business manager of the Km "Hullabaloo." He is a good all-round
man.
Mr. Weber, who will be graduated as a bachelor of arts next
June, is the president of the Grotins Society. He is also an assistant editor of THE NEws-LETTER, sings first bass in the Glee
Club, and is a member of the Instrumental Club.
Charles Leland Getz. '13, is still
in the competition. Getz was a
mighty worker while in collerre,
and has a tremendous list after his
name in the 1913 year book. He
ran a sharp race for the scholarship last year with Emory Niles.
But it is believed that family objections may keep "Getzie" from
offering his name.
The winner of the scholarship is
sure to be a Hopkins man. The
Selection by the three presidents
will be made before Christmas.

Owing to the death of Homer
Wray, one of the members of their
squad, the Gettysburg football team
was unable to play the game with
Hopkins scheduled for last Saturday. The announcement of this
fact caused much disappointment
among the Hopkins rooters, for all
had expected to see a well-played
contest.
The Hopkins football team went
in a body to Oriole Park to see
St. John's play Washington College, in hopes of getting an idea
of what kind of game St. John's
may be expected to put up next
Thursday.

Details of Wray's Death.

Gettysburg, Pa., November 22.—
Homer H. Wray, of Leechburg,
Pa., a student at Gettysburg College, died late last night from the
effects of an injury sustained in a
football game between the Gettysburg and Dickinson College reserve
teams at Carlisle three weeks ago.
Wray had one of the bones in his
chest fractured. Abscesses formed
on the lungs and caused his death.
St. John's Next.

The 'Varsity has now but one
more game, and that the most important of the season, to play. St.
John's will be no easy opponent,
and realizing this the Black and
Blue will put in the three hardest
days of practice of the year, beginning today. There will be scrimmage today and tomorrow, and
light signal drills Wednesday.
Hopkins is favored to win the
battle against St. John's, but the
odds are slight in betting. The
teams are about equal in weight.
A great turnout of Hopkins and
St. John's rooters is expected.
Both student bodies will have bands.
St. John's its student organization
and Hopkins hired talent. The
rooters will assemble at headquarters and parade to the field.
Hopkins cheering and demonstrations will be in charge of "Butts"
Sutton. St. John's has a number
of leaders.
Should Hopkins win it will have,
lost four and won three games during the season. As the defeats
were mostly at the hands of such
teams as Swarthmore and Carlisle,
whom Hopkins could not hope to
beat, the Hopkins followers do not
feel ashamed of the record of their
team. Stevens and Western Maryland have been the only teams to
fall before the Black and Blue this
season.

THE NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 24, 1913.

JOEL GUTMAN & CO.

MEETING OF GROTIUS SOCIETY

WHAT CLASS OF 1912 IS DOING

112 to 122 N. Eutaw St.

Fall Election of Officers Was Held Last
Tuesday—Mr. Hammond Renders
Some Choice Selections.

Various Vocations of Some of the Members Who Are in Pursuit of the
Coin of the Realm.

The Grotius Society held its
regular meeting at one o'clock last
Tuesday in the Donovan Room. A
quorum of seniors was present.
The fall election of officers was
held, the following being elected:
I. W. Nachlas, '][4., president;
H. W. Richmond, '14, vice-president; A. Schaffer,
secretary;
A. R. Gminder, '14, treasurer, and
C. S. Levy, '15, curator.
The discussion announced for the
meeting was woman suffrage, but
this led on to the question of women in general. Mr. A. L. Hammond read some choice selections
from Schopenhauer's remarks on
women. Not all those present
agreed with the philosopher, especially when he says such things
as: "It is only the man whose intellect is clouded by his sexual impulses that could give the name of
the fair sex to that undersized, narrow-shouldered, broad-hipped and
short-legged race !" The discussion
was very interesting to all who attended. The officers of the Society
regret that not more of the new
men are showing interest. All students will be welcome at the next
meeting—Tuesday, at one, Donovan
Room.

H. G. Du Bois, A.B.'12, is teaching at the Jefferson School.
G. P. Thomas III is with his
father in the rubber business.
Harry Dickey, A.B. '12, is working in his father's cotton mills in
the city.
Dudley Carrol, A.B. '12, is with
the street railroad company at
Portland, Ore.
"Jimmy" Easter, A.B. '12. after
surviving one year at Boston Tech:
is trying to repeat.
James Johnston Corner, Jr., A.B.
'12, and T. Brooke Price, A.B. '12,
are at the Harvard Law School.
"Bill" Gail, A.B. '12, who started
to go to Tech. with "Jimmy," but
soon quit, is now studying engineering at Cornell.
H. S. Applebaum, A.B. '12; W.
E. Grempler, A.B. '12, and A. C.
Sutton, A.B. '12, are at the Johns
Hopkins Medical School.
M. E. Hopkins, A.B. '12 ; "Johnny" Huck, A.B.'is; "Freddie" Lee,
A.B. '12; Huntley Lloyd, A.B. '12,
and Max Paulus, A.B. '12, are all
taking ,graduate work in chemistry
at the University.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOV. 24, 1913.
We're Ready, St. John's!

"Come on, St. John's, we're
ready !" We are drawing to a close
a football season that has been
fraught with surprises and disappointments, but we still have that
same sand in our makeup and hair
on our chests that took the vigor
and enjoyment out of your serpentine gyrations on the field year before last. Your snake dance then
was spiritless. It was just a matterof-fact affair that was but a worm's
wiggle to our piedbal claimant.
Your dance will be the same Thursday, that is, if there is any at all.
We are going to win the battle,
St. John's! Harsh words, but true.
Our boys are there. And we shall
'• be there, too. You will see us sitting in the west end of the east
grandstand with our hired band.
Smiles will be on our faces and a
big total on our side of the scoreboard. And we are going to sing
those beautiful songs. We are going to call you "Naughty Boy."
Our hired cymbals and b-flat cornets are going to penetrate the air
with paens of great joy and thanksgiving. It will be pretty to observe,
as "Pepys" would say.
So, come up, St. John's! Come
up with your shoes shined and your
dress uniforms all pressed up nice
and sleek, as the St. John's Collegian always urges you to do when
you take a visit with your team.
We want to see you all again. We
like to hear your pretty band and
see the"cold, red cheeks of your
student bass hornist suddenly give
up their big jowl of merry wind
as your passes are incompleted.
Come on, St. John's, we're
ready! In the glistening sphere of
fate we see eleven men downcast in
black with miriads of yellow stripes
around their arms slowly retreating

The Honor System.

THE NEWS-LETTER prints in a
prominent place on the first page of
this issue the set of resolutions
framed by the Student Council that
are intended to put all undergraduates on their honor during examinations, provided the student body
adopts the resolutions at a massmeeting to be held at i o'clock
Wednesday in Hopkins Hall.
It may appear from the prominence given the matter, however,
that dishonesty during examinations
has come to be flagrant at the Hopkins, but we are glad to be able to
say that it has not.
Every school, college and university in this and other countries has
had, at some time or other, among
its students some who have violated
the confidence placed in them by
professors and instructors, and
Hopkins has had a few such men.
The Student Council has been
prompted to try to make this few
none. Its resolutions convey the
spirit and idea of abolishment.
They are to be presented to the students, and debate and amendments
will be in order. But, however
few or many be the changes in the
resolutions, it is intended that they
will finally be adopted, with the idea
that undergraduates in the examination rooms will be under a moral
pledge not to receive or furnish
any assistance.
The Council's initiative in this
matter is highly commendable. It
has, on several other occasions, won
victories in the regulation of student affairs, and all of them have
been steps forward in self-government. Its latest plan, that to put
in practice the honor system, is
especially fine in spirit, and it is
to be hoped that Wednesday's
mass-meeting will be a notable
gathering of students demanding
the abolishment of all semblances
of dishonesty and the establishment
of a high code of student morals.
We Sympathize With Gettysburg.

The entire student body of the
Johns Hopkins University is distressed at the news of the death of
Homer H. Wray, of the Gettysburg football squad.
Hopkins knows how the Soldiers
feel now that one of their men has
fallen on the field, a martyr to football. Closed gates and a quiet field
at Homewood were our share of the
sadness, but that can not compare
with the gloom that rests on the
Pennsylvania college today.
We sympathize with Gettysburg.

Class Tournament Planned.

The Johns Hopkins Chess Club
held its reorganization meeting in
the chapel last Thursday. Officers
elected for the ensuing year are as
follows: President,Yokoyama ; vicepresident,Chenoweth,'14; secretary,
Schaffer, '14. The officers constitute the executive committee.
It was definitely decided to drop
last year's uncompleted tournament
and to start a new round-robin as
soon as possible. Those who desire
to enter the tournament should
hand their 'lames to one of the
board. The entry fee, a nominal
one, is twenty-five cents. Three
handsome prizes will be awarded to
the winners of the tournament.
The Society will challenge the
chess club of the University of
Georgetown to a match to be held
in the Hopkins Club about the middle of January. A team of six men
will be picked from those who come
out highest in the tournament, and
as all but two of last year's team,
which beat Georgetown, is back, we
have good hopes of repeating our
victory Of last year.

The annual public meeting of the
Federated Charities of Baltimore
will take place in McCoy Hall at 8
o'clock Tuesday. The annual business meeting of the Association will
be held in the rooms of the City
Club today (Monday).
These meetings are always of
great importance to those interested
in charity. At the McCoy Hall
meeting reports will be made by the
heads of the departments.
Hon. Charles P. Neill will speak
on "Organized Charities and Modern Social Problems." Mr. Neill
is chairman of the Labor Commission of the American Smelting and
Refining Company and ex-United
States Commissioner of Labor.

MID - CITY TERMINALS

successful at many other institutions where it has been adopted.
A very good example of this fact
is what happened at one of the
largest boarding schools in the
United States, where I went before
I came here. In the senior dormitory, as in all dormitories, smoking
was prohibited. The enforcement
of this rule wa's carried out, as well
as possible, by the masters in the
"dorm." However, the architecture
of the building offered many Opportunities for smoking without being
caught. The masters (lid their best
to stop it, but where there are so
many boys together it is hard to
know what each other is doing, and
the smoking in the "dorm" grew
worse and worse. Finally, after a
meeting of the house was called, we
agreed that every fellow would be
put on his honor not to smoke in
the "dorm." It worked to perfection and re-established friendships
between masters and boys,which had
been broken up on account of the
formers' everlasting spying. Only
one fellow, I may add, was ever
caught doing it after this agreement
and he was tended to sufficiently
by the rest of us.
This is my own experience of
\\ hat an excellent thing the "honor
system.' is and I sincerely hope
that it will be adopted here.
